p: Pooja Mohan received her Master of Science degree in 2000, Master of Philosophy degree in 2002, and Ph.D. degree in 2008, all in Operational Research from the University of Delhi, India. She is currently working as an Analyst in the Risk Modeling group of RMSI Pvt. Ltd, India. Her research interests include reliability, risk analysis, and distributions of runs and patterns.

Manju Agarwal (M'07) is a Professor in the Department of Operational Research, University of Delhi, India and presently also Dean, Faculty of Mathematical Sciences, University of Delhi, India. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree in Math in 1964, Master of Science in 1966, and Ph.D. degree in 1981, both in Operational Research from the University of Delhi, India. Her research interests are in system reliability optimization, multi-state system reliability, lattice path combinatorics in queuing theory, and distributions of runs and patterns. She has published more than 80 papers in scientific journals of international repute. She is a member of IEEE, and INFORMS.

Kanwar Sen is a retired Professor of Statistics from the University of Delhi, India. He received his Bachelor of Science degree from Agra University; and Master of Science and Ph.D. degrees in Mathematical Statistics, both from University of Delhi, India. His present research focuses on lattice path combinatorics in queuing theory, distributions of runs and patterns, and reliability life testing. He is author, and coauthor of more than 110 research papers in these fields.

details.abstract: This paper proposes a new model, a combined m-consecutive-k-out-of-n : F & consecutive-k<sub>c</sub>-out-of-n : F system, consisting of n components ordered in a line such that the system fails iff there exist at least k<sub>c</sub> consecutive failed components, or at least m non-overlapping runs of k consecutive failed components, where k<sub>c</sub> < mk. The components are assumed to be i.i.d. An algorithm for system reliability evaluation, along with an illustrative numerical example, is provided based on the analysis of the system using graphical evaluation and review technique (GERT). The algorithm is also evaluated in terms of the order of computational time. This model has applications to various complex systems such as infrared (IR) detecting and signal processing, and bank automatic payment systems.

links.abstract: A computer program is described for obtaining the reliability of a system composed of a number of interconnected sub-systems. The interconnections are such that at least r successive interconnected subsystems must fail in order for the system to fail. The approach treats the system as a dynamic redundant system and is implemented in a digital computer program. The program listing and examples are given in a Supplement.

context.text: It has prompted great interest since Kontoleon first studied it in 1980 [1].

references.text: J. M. Kontoleon, "Reliability determination of \$r\$-successive-out-of- \$n:{rm F}\$ system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 29, pp. 437, 1980.

links.abstract: A reliability diagram with n components in sequence is called consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system if the system fails whenever k consecutive components are failed. This paper presents a recursive formula to compute the exact system reliability, and gives sharp upper and lower bounds for it.

context.text: During the last quarter century, a great amount of research, e.g., Chiang & Niu [2], Hwang [3], Fu [4], Lambiris & Papastavridis [5], Chang et al. [6], Huang et al. [7], Levitin [8], Yamamoto et al. [9], has been investigated on \$C(k,n:{\rm F})\$, and its various generalizations, addressing problems of reliability computation.

references.title:
Reliability of a consecutive-<ref_formula>
<tex Notation="TeX">$k$</tex></ref_formula>-out-of-<ref_formula><tex Notation="TeX">$n:{\rm
F}$</tex></ref_formula> system
references.text: D. T. Chiang, S. C. Niu, "Reliability of a consecutive- \$k\$-out-of-\$n:{rm F}\$ system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 30, pp. 87-89, 1981.

links.abstract: The previous literature on consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems gives recursive equations for the system reliability only for the special case when all component reliabilities are equal. This paper gives recursive equations for the more general case when the component reliabilities can be different from each other. Furthermore, reliabilities can be computed more quickly from these recursive equations than those previously given.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system, with n linearly or circularly arranged i.i.d. components is examined. The system reliability has an exact formula which is straight forward and more effective than those given elsewhere; the two formulas are given.

links.abstract: This paper proposes a new model which generalizes the linear consecutive k-out-of-r-from-n system to the case of multiple failure criteria. In this model, the system consists of n linearly ordered elements, and fails iff in any group of r/sub 1/,...,r/sub H/ consecutive elements less than k/sub 1/,...,k/sub H/ elements respectively are in a working state. An algorithm for system reliability evaluation is suggested which is based on an extended universal moment generating function. Examples of sy...

links.abstract: In this paper, we provide an algorithm for evaluating the system state distribution for any multi-state consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system including the decreasing multi-state G system, the increasing multi-state G system, and other G systems. We evaluated our proposed algorithms in terms of the orders of computation time, and memory requirement. Furthermore, we conducted a numerical experiment to determine the actual computation time. Our proposed algorithm is more effective for systems with a lar...

links.abstract: An m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system, introduced by W.S. Griffith, consists of an ordered linear sequence of n i.i.d. components that fails iff there are at least m non-overlapping runs of k consecutive failed components. However, a situation may occur in which an ordered linear sequence of n i.i.d. components fails iff there are at least m non-overlapping runs of at least k consecutive failed components. We call such a system an m-consecutive-at least-k-out-of-n:F system. This paper presents a ...

context.text: [14] introduced a system in which an ordered linear sequence of \$n\$ i.i.d. components fails iff there are at least \$m\$ non-overlapping runs of at least \$k\$ consecutive failed components, and called such a system an \$m\$-consecutive-at least-\$k\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ system.

[14] provided explicit closed form formulae for the reliability evaluation of \$m\$-consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ system, and \$m\$-consecutive-at least-\$k\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ system in a unified manner using GERT.

links.abstract: Based on a real industrial application, three new system reliability models are proposed: combined k-out-of-n:F and consecutive-k/sub c/-out-of-n:F system; combined k-out-of-m/spl middot/n:F and linear connected-(r,s)-out-of-(m,n):F system; and combined k-out-of-m/spl middot/n:F consecutive-k/sub c/-out-of-n:F and linear connected-(r,s)-out-of-(m,n):F system. Reliability evaluation algorithms are provided for these models. The computation times of the algorithms for these models are, respectivel...

[15] proposed several new reliability models that are obtained by combining the \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$ models with other consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$ models:

•
Combined \$k\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ & consecutive-\$k_{c}\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ system,
•
Combined \$k\$-out-of-\$mn:{\rm F}\$ & linear connected-\$(r,s)\$-out-of-\$(m, n):{\rm F}\$ system, and
•
Combined \$k\$-out-of-\$mn:{\rm F}\$ & consecutive-\$k_{c}\$-out-of-\$n:{\rm F}\$ system & connected-\$(r,s)\$-out-of-\$(m, n):{\rm F}\$ system.

links.abstract: Qualification tests for a system are normally carried out according to either a k-out-of-n:G scheme, or a consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G structure. The reliability of a combination of the two systems is evaluated, showing its benefit over each of the individual structures. As expected, the mean time to failure of the combined system is larger than any of them. Generalizations of the analysis are presented for tests with multi-state results, and for dependent tests. Illustrative numerical result...

context.text: In addition, Agarwal & Mohan [18], using GERT, studied a situation in which a system consisting of a sequence of \$n\$ linearly ordered components fails iff there are at least \$m\$ overlapping runs of \$k\$ consecutive failed components for both i.i.d. components, and \$(k-1)\$-step Markov dependent components.

references.text: M. Agarwal, P. Mohan, "GERT analysis of \$m\$ -consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n:{rm F}\$ system with overlapping runs and \$(k-1)\$-step Markov dependence", International Journal of Operational Research, vol. 3, no. 1/2, pp. 36-51, 2008.

context.text: Mason's Rule (Whitehouse [19], pp. 168–172): In an open flow graph, write down the product of transmittances along each path from the independent variable to the dependent variable.

Sum these modified path transmittances, and divide by the sum of all the loops in the open flow graph yielding transmittance T as where For more necessary details about GERT, one can see Whitehouse [19], Cheng [20], and Agarwal et al. [14].

context.text: Malinowski & Preuss [21], [22] provide algorithms for the reliability evaluation of multi-state consecutively connected systems using a tree structure, and a reverse tree structure.
